body:
This is intended as a discussion point on if this needs to be in an rc5 for 0.8.3, or if it can wait until 0.9.0

I have to include it locally in my testing regardless of the community decision around an rc5
@navis latest changes looks fine to me, can we squash commits before merging. @cheddar there have been quite a few changes since your last thumbs up, can you have a second look?
@xvrl Sure, let me check #2040
Is this from https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2015#issuecomment-170374132 ?
yes
see https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2238
:+1:. I think this module will not impact much in Druid and is solving the use cases of an organization
@binlijin any chance we can add some docs, tests, and finish this one up?
@navis Following up on this PR, any updates on addressing @vogievetsky's comments so we can get this in?

@himanshug Any more comments?

@KurtYoung Can we add some way to switch between IndexMerger and IndexMerger v9 in the configuration? Index Merger should be the default.
@binlijin any updates on the performance improvements?

@binlijin I _think_ this is changing the behavior of topN. I also think the situation you describe is something that https://github.com/implydata/pivot is doing with its nested topNs.

Is this correct? If so, I think we may consider a native query type to better support nested topNs.
@fjy I am :+1: once the configuration to switch to IndexMergerV9 is in place.
PR is void of unit tests

I believe @cheddar should have a look at this one. He had a lot of opinions about format when I made changes to introduce dimension compression, and this one introduces even more changes.

I also agree with @gianm we should be able to switch between implementations until it has been verified to be production ready.

we can rename kafka-indexing-service to just kafka-indexing or may be I'm overthinking?

regarding scope, I would move the kafka module in a separate PR and do (2) in this PR itself. That said, I will let you take the final call on that.

"Out of curiosity why do you prefer to have the tranquility stuff here instead of the kafka stuff?"
to get you focused on that and have stuff working for tranquility as early as possible.

also, I dint realize that (2) was going to be "tranquility specific" code, i thought that was core druid change and not a new module.

Haha, ok :)

I actually had been doing the tranquility stuff first and then took a detour through the kafka stuff as I think it is a lot simpler, and wanted to get some kind of initial thing working. The tranquility stuff ended up getting kind of complicated. I plan to go back to that soon though. But in the meantime, some review on this stuff would be great.

agree with @nishantmonu51 regarding performance hit. I think, following workarounds can be used  to fulfill use case in #2061
1) in the ETL step create additional column in data which has 1 if filter condition is ok or 0 if not, then use a longSum aggregator on that colunn.
2) create custom druid InputRowParser to introduce above column on the fly when druid is ingesting data.
can we separate out the travis / bugfix / formatting changes?
sure
@xvrl you want them in separate PRs or is one PR but multiple commits ok?
I'll squash commits when @cheddar approves.
@fjy It's useful in some cases but as @himanshug commented, It can use much more memory than before. Maybe some threshold numbers might be needed. Ideas?
@sirpkt How about to wrap `agg.factorize()` with `rowContainer.set(row);` and `rowContainer.set(null);` before and after? It's simple and will not affect performance.
Is https://github.com/himanshug/druid/commit/e6dbb78e54cf8a5a89a4d7f040934061685cb2b1 needed?
@drcrallen yes

Generally, it's implemented in accordant with current implementation but cartesian is still looks painful. I think we should reorder filters and merge bitmap from simple filter with one from complex like this to minimize the pain (when AND filter is applied). But it can be handled in following issue.
ok, minor question at https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2244/files#r49402761 , but since this is a backport and the question is in a test I'm :+1:
@navis I noticed the changes here conflict with PR #2169, what are your future plans for this PR?

@navis I'm working on some non-String typing changes to IncrementalIndex, and I want to get this PR in before I submit a PR for that, can you squash the commits if you don't have any more changes?

@fjy @drcrallen @nishantmonu51 I plan on merging this after the squash, do you have any more feedback on this?
@jon-wei Merge any non-commited PR on any commited PR? Don't have any special plan, but I expect some following works can be started from this PR.
@jon-wei Squashed
is https://github.com/navis/druid/commit/3f0c8cddc23c7154d9f323213fee9d264dc39f1f showing up for anyone else in this PR?
yeah, I think @navis you may have grabbed more commits than you meant to.
I see that CliPeon commit as well
Sorry, my bad.
Sorry, my bad.

Everyone worries about performance degradation, and I agree with that.
@navis I think it is perfect way to avoid NPE for OnHeapIncrementalIndex,
But it does not work with OffHeapIncrementalIndex, where agg.factorize() is called even before addToFacts, so I passed that approach.

However, if I change OffHeapIncrementalIndex code a little, I think I can make it work.
I'll try that approach.
`OffHeapIncrementalIndex` is destined to be removed (it's included in some patches, like #2085, etc.). so it would not be a problem.

https://travis-ci.org/druid-io/druid/jobs/101730020

```
AnnouncerTest.testSanity:101 »  test timed out after 60000 milliseconds
```
@binlijin can you format your top comment with markdown? I'm having a hard time parsing which parts are code and which are sentences.
@b-slim the un-official method is to put [WIP], but in general if you don't think it would be ready for code review in a few days then it probably should be closed until ready for discussion.
@drcrallen, sorry for my mistake.

@xvrl I am more in favor of `Announcer` for internal announcements rather than `CuratorServiceAnnouncer` as its API gives more freedom on announcing stuff(Druid server metadata, leadership info, etc.) and it's already being used by Historical/Realtime to announce segments. This also means there should be an internal DruidServiceClients that discover Druid services announced internally.

That said, `CuratorServiceAnnouncer` should only be used for external discovery. Regarding announcing on a different Zookeeper cluster, we can annotate `CuratorFramework` differently for internal and external usages.
Having only the whitelist be dynamically configurable seems like a reasonable way to go.
http://druid.io/docs/latest/ingestion/faq.html

@navis Cool, I wanted to know if you were going to update this PR for IncrementalIndex after #2169's merge, just something for me to keep in mind. I am working on a patch that loosens the types for dimensions in IncrementalIndex that I plan on submitting a PR for in the next few days.
@fjy，done
@drcrallen addressed comments.
@jon-wei Good to know. All theses refactoring are intended for that kind of issues because we also need numeric type dimensions. I'll rebase this.
not sure about this one just yet
@fjy ok, i will add a config about this. Also looking forward to @cheddar 's comments :)
:+1:, looks good to me with multiple commits.
Why does DruidNode need this?
@himanshug do we need RC6?
Rebased on trunk and squashed commit lists

Updated based on the review comments.
By the way, @navis I totally agree with you that cartesian is really painful
and hope your patch relieves it.

You are welcome. I think that after merging PR #2058, a broker has got to know uncovered intervals, which represent absent data segments. So If we want to have a query result zero-filled on absent data segments, we can use that information to put zeros among data segments in a query result.

@drcrallen "PR is void of unit tests" Considering this module is sort of connector, it's unlikely to provide really useful unit tests without setting up messaging system and druid. Also, I just checked kafka-eight module, it lacks unit test too.

@xvrl thanks - I had tried those instructions but kept getting this error:
"Error checking TLS connection: Host is not running"after eval "$(docker-machine env default)".
@fjy i don't particularly need it, @drcrallen has a open mail thread about rc-5, added this PR there.
:+1: after https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2149/files#r49475041 and https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2149/files#r49477224 are resolved.

I propose the following fix (assuming we do not want to support asking to merge metrics that are not present in any of the indices we are actually merging (i.e. you need to know the exact schema of the indices you are merging)):

afe15cf952617030d9bf4322285f5484c7a31640

The error is now properly reported, and clear.
@sirpkt Offheap incremental index should be removed. It is not production ready and no one is using it.

If we choose to support merge as I originally expected it to work, I propose the following:

0580be68cd87dbae257f9c2311ce1a648e063ad9

You must still specify at least all of the metrics contained in the union of the indices you are merging, but if you specify additional metrics, they do not break things.

`io.druid.query.dimension.RegexFilteredDimensionSpecTest` has no tests for correctness. This makes the correctness of this patch harder to judge.

If I'm reading this correctly, the error comes from the fact that the topN is returning ALL dimension values in a multi-value dimension instead of just the ones that match the filter, is that correct?

If so, then it would make more sense to me to have the topN function as expected. From the contract on `io.druid.segment.DimensionSelector#getValueCardinality` it LOOKS like `io.druid.query.dimension.RegexFilteredDimensionSpec#decorate` is behaving properly.

Can you comment a bit more on why the prior cardinality methods were insufficient?

@binlijin i have to dig more into the original issue you faced but  getValueCardinality() impls are doing the right thing as per the contract of those methods.
It will be useful if you could explain why existing implementations are causing problems for TopN query?
:+1:, please squash the commits.
@xvrl Added code comments about thread safety.
@guobingkun both remaining dependencies seem to have merge conflicts or are closed down. Are you able to coordinate with the other contributors to help move this forward?
:+1: after basic hashCode/equals unit tests.
rebased again to resolve merge conflicts.
@drcrallen I think this PR is reviewable now. (updated PR description).

Hi @michaelschiff thanks for the great info on this. This seems like something that should be supported properly, and seems like it could have an impact on https://groups.google.com/d/msg/druid-development/kHgHTgqKFlQ/fXvtsNxWzlMJ . @gianm
:+1: looks good to me
Could you also add some unit tests that demonstrate behavior of out of order aggregators? (like C, A, B) and if those work assuming the full set is present, what happens if some are missing?
@fjy I have some unit tests in other PRs that use the equals method of DruidNode. namely Objects.equals(X, Y) where X and Y contain DruidNode fields.
And the IntelliJ generated equals function just checks the equals methods of the fields.

@pjain1 there's a lot of places that assume a 10ms sleep is sufficient to resolve lock contention fairness. Do any of the lock actions block on lock acquisition? If so it would make more sense to me to have a fair queue enforced on the overlord's side on lock contention rather than trying to rely on sleeping threads to allow lock fairness.
@nishantmonu51 I think the commits are pretty distinct and don't need to be squashed
@himanshug, how does this pass unit tests? I'm surprised no UT caught this

@genevien I added the tests and docs for you here: https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2258

Closing this PR.

@fjy FilteredDimensionSpec is new feature and is tested with groupBy queries in the unit tests. looks like TopN can't handle the new DimensionSpec with correct cardinality implementation for some reason.

I have verified that all of navis's changes since I looked last are good on the basic functionality.  I did not verify that the caching looks good, but I'm happy with everyone else's eyes on that.  so I'm :+1:
@nishantmonu51 / @himanshug Fixed merge conflicts any other comments?
